meta.title: 8.2 Properties of hypothesis test
intro.title: Properties of hypothesis test
regions.title: Regions
regions.p1: Let the two possible decisions of a (nonrandomized) test be denoted by d_0 (accept H) and d_1 (reject H). A test assigns to each possible sample point x a decision, thereby partitioning the sample space into two complementary regions.
regions.p2: We write S_0 for the acceptance region and S_1 for the rejection (critical) region.
regions.def.title: Critical region (rejection region)
regions.def.p1: The set S_1 of all sample points X for which we reject the null hypothesis H is called the critical (or rejection) region. Its complement S_0 is the acceptance region.
regions.p3: In practice, we design S_1 to control the probability of rejecting H when H is true, while keeping good detection when H is false.
true.title: When H is true: significance and size
true.p1: If H is true but X falls in the rejection region S_1, we have made a false alarm. We want to keep this probability small.
true.sig.title: Level of significance and size
true.sig.p1: For a real number \(\alpha \in (0,1)\), a test has level (significance) \(\alpha\) if under all parameters in the null, the rejection probability is at most \(\alpha\):
true.p2: is called the size of the test (or of the critical region S_1). A good level-\(\alpha\) test has size close to \(\alpha\) but not exceeding it.
power.title: When H is wrong: power
power.p1: When the alternative is true, we would like the test to reject H with high probability.
power.p2: For a given parameter value \(\theta \in \Theta_1\), the power is the probability of correctly rejecting H:
stat.title: Test statistic and critical function
stat.p1: A test statistic T is a function of the sample that tends to be small when H is true and large when H is false (or vice versa).
stat.p2: A critical value c is selected so that we reject H when, for example, \(T(X) \ge c\) and accept otherwise (one–sided case).

err.title: Errors
err.p0: There are two types of error we can make (not simultaneously).
err.li1: Type I error: H is true but \(X \in S_1\) (we reject when we should accept).
err.li2: Type II error: H is false but \(X \notin S_1\) (we accept when we should reject).
err.p1: By convention, we control the Type I error probability at level \(\alpha\) and then design a test with as much power as possible against alternatives.
